abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Power Distribution
            and Transmission Project for Sri Lanka was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its major objectives, its impact on
            institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of the Bank
            was satisfactory while the Borrower's was marginally
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, advance procurement actions should be tied
            up with the various stages of project processing. Second,
            CEB's financial authority to handle procurement
            decisions should be enhanced. Third, during the initial
            stages of project preparation, comprehensive training
            programs with the objective of overall institutional
            strengthening should be developed and agreed upon. Fourth,
            security risks should be properly evaluated and works in
            security prone areas should not be included in the scope of
            future projects. Fifth, efforts should be made by the CEB to
            develop local contractors for the erection of power lines
            and sub-stations. Finally, land acquisition and compensation
            procedures should be simplified.
